DOCNAME: CASES OF HARKINS AND EDWARDS v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
CONCLUSION: Remainder inadmissible;No violation of Article 3 - Prohibition of torture (Article 3 - Extradition) (Conditional) (United States of America);No violation of Article 3 - Prohibition of torture (Article 3 - Extradition) (Conditional) (United States of America)
JUDGES: David Thór Björgvinsson;George Nicolaou;Lech Garlicki;Nicolas Bratza;Päivi Hirvelä;Vincent A. De Gaetano;Zdravka Kalaydjieva
TEXT: CARDINAL . On DATE , in GPE , GPE , PERSON was killed by a gunshot wound to the head in the course of a robbery .

The first applicant was subsequently arrested for the murder of Mr PERSON and , on DATE , was indicted for first degree murder and attempted robbery with a firearm . On DATE the prosecution filed a notice that they intended to seek the death penalty for the charge of first degree murder ; that notice was subsequently withdrawn . According to an affidavit filed in support of the GPE extradition request by Mr PERSON , Assistant ORG Attorney ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , the prosecution case is based upon the testimony of a co - accused , Mr PERSON , who has since confessed and become a witness for the prosecution . His evidence is that he and the first applicant arranged for Mr PERSON to purchase marijuana from the first applicant . A meeting was arranged for delivery and payment . Mr PERSON and the first applicant arrived at the meeting wearing masks . According to PERSON , the first applicant brandished a rifle and , when Mr PERSON refused to hand over the money , the first applicant shot him in the head . Mr PERSON and the first applicant fled the scene , washed blood from their car at a carwash and threw the rifle in a river . The prosecution further rely on ballistics evidence , and other witnesses whom they intend to call at trial to prove that the applicant planned the robbery and left his residence with a gun shortly before the robbery and killing .

The applicant maintains that initial police reports into Mr Hayes’ murder record PERSON as stating that he , the first applicant , hit Mr PERSON in the head with the gun and the gun went off . The police reports also directly refer to the killing as CARDINAL of “ felony murder ” . ( The GPE “ felony murder rule ” allows a defendant to be convicted of murder , even if there was no premeditation on his part , if he committed or was attempting to commit a serious felony offence ( including armed robbery ) at the time of the killing : see relevant GPE law at paragraph CARDINAL below . ) The applicant also maintains that the medical examiner ’s report on Mr Hayes’ injuries demonstrates that the injuries are consistent with the gun going off accidentally . However , the first applicant denies being present at the fatal incident : he alleges that he only lent his car to CARDINAL of those present , a Mr Randle , who went on to participate in the fatal robbery of PERSON .
After he was indicted , the applicant was released on bail and ordered to appear before the court on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE , the first applicant was arrested in GPE following a fatal car accident , for which he was subsequently sentenced to DATE imprisonment . An extradition request was made by ORG on DATE . In an affidavit provided in support of the extradition request , Mr PERSON , Assistant ORG Attorney , confirmed that the notice of intention to seek the death penalty had been withdrawn and that the prosecution sought a life sentence .

CARDINAL . On DATE the District Judge sitting at FAC concluded that the evidence established a prima facie case against the first applicant and ordered that he be committed to prison to await the decision of the Secretary of ORG as to his surrender to GPE .

CARDINAL . In a Diplomatic Note issued on DATE ORG assured ORG that , based on an assurance ORG had received from the ORG Attorney of ORG , the death penalty would not be sought or imposed on the first applicant .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Secretary of ORG refused the first applicant ’s representations and ordered his surrender . On the basis of the assurance from ORG , the Secretary of ORG concluded that the death penalty would not be imposed on the first applicant and that extradition would not otherwise violate the first applicant ’s rights under the Convention .

CARDINAL . The applicant sought judicial review of the Secretary of ORG ’s decision by ORG . He argued inter alia that the assurance contained in the Diplomatic Note was inadequate because it had been issued by ORG whereas the prosecution would be conducted by ORG and only an assurance from the ORG Governor would suffice . He further argued that the trial court in GPE was enabled by the applicable criminal procedure to consider the imposition of the death penalty irrespective of whether or not it was sought by the prosecution .

CARDINAL . A further affidavit was then submitted by the GPE Assistant ORG Attorney , Mr PERSON , who stated that , as a matter of long - standing practice , the trial court would not conduct a sentencing hearing to decide whether to impose the death penalty when the ORG Attorney did not seek the death penalty ; even if it were to do so , the ORG Attorney would not present any evidence in support of the death penalty , meaning that there would be no basis upon which the trial court could find there were sufficient aggravating circumstances to warrant the death penalty . Mr GPE therefore stated that the first applicant would not be subjected to the death penalty if he were convicted of first degree felony murder .

CARDINAL . On the basis of this affidavit , and on the further basis that the Diplomatic Note was clear and binding as a matter of international law , ORG found there was no real risk of the death penalty and accordingly refused the application for judicial review . On DATE , CARDINAL DATE , it also refused the first applicant ’s application for certification of a point of law and permission to appeal to ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE , the applicant ’s solicitor informed the Secretary of ORG that an application had been made to ORG for reconsideration of its decision . He relied on the affidavit sworn by an NORP attorney , which stated that the trial court could in fact impose the death penalty if sufficient aggravating features were found to exist in the first applicant ’s case . By way of an order dated DATE , ORG Judge PERSON , the trial judge in the first applicant ’s case , stated that no death penalty sentencing proceedings would be held and therefore the maximum sentence that could be imposed would be life in prison . It does not appear that the first applicant made an application to ORG or that any such application was determined by that court .

CARDINAL . On DATE the first applicant lodged an application with this ORG and , on DATE , the President of the ORG to which the application was allocated decided to apply Rule CARDINAL of ORG and to indicate to the Government of GPE that the applicant should not be extradited until further notice . It was also decided , under LAW ) , that notice of the application should be given to ORG of GPE and that the Government should be invited to submit written observations on the admissibility and merits of the case , including on whether any life sentence imposed on the first applicant would be compatible with LAW .

CARDINAL . After the Government ’s observations had been received , the first applicant indicated that he had submitted fresh representations to the Secretary of ORG on the issue of the imposition of a life sentence . Those representations were made on DATE . Further submissions were made in the light of the ORG of Lords’ judgment in GPE v. the Secretary of ORG for ORG ( see paragraphs DATE CARDINAL below ) on DATE , DATE and DATE . Proceedings before this Court were therefore adjourned while those representations were considered by the Secretary of ORG .

CARDINAL . NORP The Secretary of ORG refused the first applicant ’s representations on DATE , relying in particular on this ORG ’s judgment in PERSON v. GPE [ ORG ] , no . CARDINAL , DATE and the GPE judgment , cited above . He noted that , on the basis of information provided by the first applicant and the United States’ authorities , DATE the Governor had commuted the sentences of CARDINAL defendants who had been convicted of first - degree murder . Although he was not constrained as to the factors he could take into account in granting clemency , the Governor took in account inter alia the nature of the offence and any history of mental instability . Moreover , the sentence of life imprisonment without parole had only been introduced in DATE . It was not unrealistic to assume that defendants who had received that sentence would be expected to serve CARDINAL to fifteen years before being considered for clemency and thus it was immaterial that the Governor had not granted clemency to anyone who had been given that sentence .

CARDINAL . NORP The Secretary of ORG also had regard to the first applicant ’s representations that GPE law allowed for the imposition of a mandatory sentence of life imprisonment without parole either for : ( i ) premeditated murder ; or ( ii ) if the defendant committed or was attempting to commit a serious felony offence ( including armed robbery ) at the time the person was killed ( the “ felony murder rule ” ) . Having regard to the circumstances of the crime of which the first applicant had been accused , the Secretary of ORG was not satisfied that a sentence of life imprisonment without parole , even as a result of the felony murder rule , was grossly disproportionate . This conclusion was not altered by the applicant ’s young age at the time of the offence , or the fact that he had submitted a psychiatric report , which showed he suffered from a severe personality disorder , with features of narcissistic and borderline personality disorders . Both these factors amounted to only limited mitigation . The Secretary of ORG was also satisfied that no separate issues arose under LAW in respect of life imprisonment without parole or the felony murder rule .

CARDINAL . The first applicant sought judicial review of the Secretary of ORG ’s decision , arguing that mandatory life imprisonment without parole as a consequence of the felony murder rule would be in violation of LAW . ORG dismissed that application on DATE ( [ DATE ] EWHC CARDINAL ( Admin ) ) .

CARDINAL . Lord Justice PERSON ( with whom Mr Justice PERSON agreed ) considered it to be “ wholly unreal ” that the first applicant could be tried in GPE and GPE . He also applied the approach taken by ORG in GPE and , on the evidence before the court , concluded that the only mechanism for release of the first applicant was by clemency or conditional release on compassionate medical grounds . However , the clemency procedure had been from time to time exercised , despite the first applicant ’s submission that it was subject to political pressure . The fact that no one convicted of first degree murder and sentenced to life imprisonment without parole had been granted clemency did not mean that there was no prospect of clemency being granted in the future to someone thus sentenced . Lord Justice PERSON accepted the Secretary of ORG ’s submission that , given that the sentence had only existed since DATE , it was unsurprising that no one sentenced to life imprisonment without parole had yet been granted clemency .

CARDINAL . In respect of the felony murder rule , Lord Justice PERSON found that the evidence showed that it was likely that , at trial , the prosecution would seek to argue that the first applicant ’s shooting of Mr PERSON was a premeditated killing . There was , however , also a realistic possibility that the first applicant could be convicted by way of the felony murder rule and the prosecution was not bound to put the matter higher . Lord Justice PERSON observed , however , that :

“ [ T]he only ‘ accident’ involved is the accidental discharge of the loaded and cocked firearm . The killing would thus not have been premeditated but would have resulted from a serious and most dangerous assault , committed in the course of a robbery . Insofar as it is permissible to have regard to LANGUAGE PERSON ( as furnishing no more than a frame of reference ) , the most likely outcome , on that factual assumption , would be a conviction for manslaughter . Moreover , it would involve a very grave case of manslaughter indeed ... On the material before us , it is fanciful to contemplate a complete acquittal on the basis of ( true ) ‘ accident’ . ”
He concluded :

“ CARDINAL . First and importantly , it is necessary to clarify the ambit of the argument before this ORG . It is not contended on behalf of Mr. PERSON that the GPE felony murder rule is unconstitutional on the ground of arbitrariness or its potential application to a wide range of circumstances and in cases of ( relatively ) low culpability . [ Counsel ’s ] submission is instead confined to the contention that , on the facts of this case , the possible conviction of Mr. PERSON by way of the GPE felony murder [ rule ] means that his extradition would be incompatible with Art . CARDINAL . It follows that some of [ counsel ’s ] more graphic examples of the scope of application of the GPE felony murder rule ( e.g. , to a man sentenced to ORG [ life imprisonment without parole ] after lending his car to friends to commit a burglary , in the course of which a woman was killed ) , can be put to CARDINAL side . ORG is concerned with the facts of this case and no question arises of accessory liability , remote from the killing ; Mr. PERSON alleged role was plainly that of principal .

CARDINAL . Secondly , the scope of the debate in this case has now been clarified . Realistically , for reasons already canvassed , this case is concerned with the possibility that Mr. PERSON will be convicted by way of the GPE felony murder rule for conduct ( at best for Mr. PERSON ) akin to manslaughter in the course of an armed robbery in this jurisdiction . It is fanciful to contemplate Mr. PERSON being at risk of conviction for what was an ‘ accident’ truly so called ; on any realistic view , there was no such ‘ accident’ here .

CARDINAL . Thirdly , it is of course a matter for the sentencing policy of the ORG of GPE whether mandatory ORG is an appropriate sentence for the crime committed in this case , if Mr. PERSON is convicted . Bearing in mind that this ORG is not engaged in a comparative sentencing exercise , it is helpful to keep the following matters in mind when considering whether , seen through ‘ the prism of an application for LOC ( GPE , supra , at [ CARDINAL ] ) the potential GPE sentence should be seen as clearly disproportionate :

i ) As this ORG is only concerned with the facts of this case , the mandatory nature of the sentence does not carry the significance which it might , had the Court been engaged in some wider review of the law in question .

ii ) The ( alleged ) facts of the present case are shocking indeed . However analysed , should Mr. PERSON be convicted , he will have committed a grave crime ; even on the most favourable ( realistic ) view of the facts for Mr. PERSON , his culpability will be high . On the ( alleged ) facts of this case , a severe sentence would be a punishment fitting the crime .

iii ) To the extent that it matters , it would be wrong to underestimate the likely sentence Mr. PERSON would face in this country , even were he convicted “ only ” of manslaughter rather than murder . It is probable that he would receive an indeterminate sentence of imprisonment for public protection ( “ IPP ” ) , although the possibility of a life sentence can not be excluded . In any event , so far as concerned the notional determinate element of an ORG or a determinate sentence if it stood alone , on the conduct alleged in the present case , Mr. PERSON could expect a significant sentence well into double figures .

CARDINAL . Fourthly , against this background , I am unable to conclude that the imposition in the GPE of a sentence of ORG on Mr. PERSON would be clearly disproportionate , although it would not be a sentence passed here . Given Mr. PERSON ( alleged ) conduct , it would not be a sentence which ‘ shocked the conscience’ . On any view , that the killing occurred in the course of an armed robbery is a most serious aggravating factor , made , if anything , yet more grave by the ( alleged ) fact that the loaded rifle had been cocked by Mr. PERSON before getting out of his car .

CARDINAL . Fifthly , although I have carefully considered Mr. Harkins’ age at the time of the incident ( he was DATE ) , I am not dissuaded by that factor from the conclusion to which I am otherwise minded to come .

CARDINAL . Sixthly , on the evidence and as already discussed , the sentence of ORG is not irreducible . The significance of this feature for the Art . CARDINAL jurisprudence was highlighted above . However , even if , contrary to my conclusion , the sentence was irreducible , on the ( alleged ) facts of this case , I would not regard the imposition of an irreducible sentence of ORG as clearly disproportionate and thus in violation of Art . DATE whatever questions might arise at some point in the course of Mr. Harkins’ detention .

CARDINAL . Pulling the threads together , the case of Mr. PERSON does involve a young ( alleged ) offender , facing a mandatory sentence of ORG . But , as the ORG is solely concerned with the facts of this case , the mandatory nature of the sentence does not have the wider significance which might otherwise attach to it . Should he be convicted , Mr. PERSON will , on any ( realistic ) view , have committed a grave crime with high culpability . The sentence of ORG is manifestly severe and different from the sentence he would face in this jurisdiction DATE but it can not be seen as clearly disproportionate . It is , moreover , not irreducible , though even if it was , the imposition of the sentence per se would not be incompatible with Art . CARDINAL . ”
CARDINAL . The first applicant then applied to ORG for a certificate of points of law of general public importance and for leave to appeal to ORG . On DATE , ORG refused both applications .

“ CARDINAL . This particular case qualifies for a maximum penalty of life imprisonment under PERSON . Criminal Law § CARDINAL - CARDINAL(b ) . The Death Penalty does not apply .

CARDINAL . Criminal Law § CARDINAL - CARDINAL and § DATE ) .

CARDINAL . In the instant case , in the event that the ORG did in fact file its notice of intention to seek life without parole , the trial judge would be the sole sentencing authority , and would have the discretion to seek a sentence of :
- life without the possibility of parole ;

- life with the possibility of parole , with all but a certain number of DATE suspended , followed by DATE of probation .
CARDINAL . In the undersigned ’s experience , there is no way to accurately predict what sentence a defendant will face if convicted of first degree murder . ”

Mr PERSON added that a person convicted of first - degree murder was entitled to a pre - sentencing investigation . The single biggest mitigating factor in regard to whether a Defendant receives life without parole would be an acceptance of responsibility upon the part of a given defendant . ”

CARDINAL . Before ORG , the second applicant accepted that his ground of appeal based on LAW was precluded by the ORG of Lords’ ruling in NORP v. PERSON ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) and conceded that it had to be dismissed . On DATE , the High Court therefore dismissed the second applicant ’s appeal on this ground , allowing only his appeal that count CARDINAL of the indictment was not an extraditable offence . CARDINAL . On DATE the second applicant lodged an application with this ORG and requested an interim measure to prevent his extradition . On DATE the President of the ORG to which this application was allocated decided to apply Rule CARDINAL of ORG and indicate to the Government of GPE that the applicant should not be extradited until further notice .

CARDINAL . For each applicant , the applicable bilateral treaty on extradition was the DATE GPE – USA Extradition Treaty ( now superseded by a DATE treaty ) . LAW DATE treaty provided that extradition could be refused unless the requesting ORG gave assurances satisfactory to the requested ORG that the death penalty would not be carried out .

CARDINAL . GPE requested the extradition of GPE from GPE to stand trial in GPE on CARDINAL counts of murder in the first degree . In his appeal against extradition , Mr GPE argued that his surrender would violate LAW , on the basis that there was a real risk that he would be subjected to inhuman and degrading treatment in the form of a sentence of life imprisonment without parole .

CARDINAL . In giving judgment in ORG ( [ DATE ] DATE ) ) , Lord Justice Laws found that there were “ powerful arguments of penal philosophy ” which suggested that risk of a whole - life sentence without parole intrinsically violated LAW . He observed :

“ The abolition of the death penalty has been lauded , and justified , in many ways ; but it must have been founded at least on the premise that the life of every person , however depraved , has an inalienable value . The destruction of a life may be accepted in some special circumstances , such as self - defence or just war ; but retributive punishment is never enough to justify it . Yet a prisoner ’s incarceration without hope of release is in many respects in like case to a sentence of death . He can never atone for his offence . However he may use his incarceration as time for amendment of life , his punishment is only exhausted by his last breath . Like the death sentence the whole - life tariff is lex talionis . But its notional or actual symmetry with the crime for which it is visited on the prisoner ( the only virtue of the lex talionis ) is a poor guarantee of proportionate punishment , for the whole - life tariff is arbitrary : it may be measured in DATE or DATE according to how long the prisoner has to live . It is therefore liable to be disproportionate – the very vice which is condemned on LAW unless , of course , the death penalty ’s logic applies : the crime is so heinous it can never be atoned for . But in that case the supposed inalienable value of the prisoner ’s life is reduced , merely , to his survival : to nothing more than his drawing breath and being kept , no doubt , confined in decent circumstances . That is to pay lip - service to the value of life ; not to vouchsafe it . ”

However , and “ not without misgivings ” , he considered that the relevant authorities , including those of this ORG , suggested an irreducible life sentence would not always raise an Article CARDINAL issue .

CARDINAL . GPE ’s appeal from that judgment was heard by ORG and dismissed on DATE . Central to the appeal was paragraph CARDINAL of this ORG ’s judgment in GPE v. GPE , DATE , LAW , Series A no . CARDINAL , where the ORG stated that considerations in favour of extradition :
“ .. must also be included among the factors to be taken into account in the interpretation and application of the notions of inhuman and degrading treatment or punishment in extradition cases . ”

CARDINAL . A majority of their Lordships , Lord PERSON , ORG and Lord PERSON , found that , on the basis of this paragraph , in the extradition context , a distinction had to be drawn between torture and lesser forms of ill - treatment . When there was a real risk of torture , the prohibition on extradition was absolute and left no room for a balancing exercise . However , insofar as LAW applied to inhuman and degrading treatment and not to torture , it was applicable only in a relativist form to extradition cases .

CARDINAL . Lord PERSON , giving the lead speech , considered the ORG ’s judgment in the case of PERSON v. GPE , DATE , § CARDINAL , Reports of Judgments and Decisions DATE , in which the ORG stated that :

“ It should not be inferred from the ORG ’s remarks [ at paragraph CARDINAL of GPE ] that there is any room for balancing the risk of ill - treatment against the reasons for expulsion in determining whether a ORG ’s responsibility under LAW ) is engaged . ”
Lord PERSON stated :

“ In the context of PERSON , I read this remark as affirming that there can be no room for a balancing of risk against reasons for expulsion when it comes to subjecting someone to the risk of torture . I do not however think that the ORG was intending to depart from the relativist approach to what counted as inhuman and degrading treatment which was laid down in GPE and which is paralleled in the cases on other articles of the LAW in a foreign context . If such a radical departure from precedent had been intended , I am sure that the ORG would have said so . ”
For Lord PERSON , paragraph CARDINAL of PERSON made clear that :

“ ... the desirability of extradition is a factor to be taken into account in deciding whether the punishment likely to be imposed in the receiving state attains the ‘ minimum level of severity’ which would make it inhuman and degrading . Punishment which counts as inhuman and degrading in the domestic context will not necessarily be so regarded when the extradition factor has been taken into account . ”
He went on to state :

“ A relativist approach to the scope of article CARDINAL seems to me essential if extradition is to continue to function . For example , ORG has decided in PERSON v Scottish Ministers ( DATE ) GPE CARDINAL that in GPE the practice of ‘ slopping out’ ( requiring a prisoner to use a chamber pot in his cell and empty it in TIME ) may cause an infringement of article CARDINAL . Whether , even in a domestic context , this attains the necessary level of severity is a point on which I would wish to reserve my opinion . If , however , it were applied in the context of extradition , it would prevent anyone being extradited to many countries , poorer than GPE , where people who are not in prison often have to make do without flush lavatories . ”

CARDINAL . A minority of their Lordships , Lord PERSON and Lord PERSON , disagreed with these conclusions . They considered that the extradition context was irrelevant to the determination of whether a whole life sentence amounted to inhuman and degrading treatment . They found no basis in the text of LAW for such a distinction . Lord PERSON also considered that the ORG , in PERSON and again in PERSON v. GPE [ ORG ] , no . CARDINAL , ORG DATE ... , had departed from the previous , relativist approach to inhuman and degrading treatment that it had taken in GPE . He stated :

“ There is , I conclude , no room in the GPE jurisprudence for a concept such as the risk of a flagrant violation of article CARDINAL ’s absolute prohibition against inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment ( akin to that of the risk of a ‘ flagrant denial of justice’ ) . By the same token that no one can be expelled if he would then face the risk of torture , so too no one can be expelled if he would then face the risk of treatment or punishment which is properly to be characterised as inhuman or degrading . That , of course , is not to say that , assuming for example ‘ slopping out’ is degrading treatment in GPE , so too it must necessarily be regarded in all countries ( see para CARDINAL of Lord PERSON ’s opinion ) ... ORG has repeatedly said that the LAW does not ‘ purport to be a means of requiring the contracting states to impose LAW standards on other states’ ( Soering , para CARDINAL ) and article CARDINAL does not bar removal to non - Convention states ( whether by way of extradition or simply for the purposes of immigration control ) merely because they choose to impose higher levels or harsher measures of criminal punishment .

Nor is it to say that a risk of article CARDINAL ill - treatment , the necessary pre - condition of an article CARDINAL bar upon extradition , will readily be established . On the contrary , as ORG reaffirmed in PERSON at para CARDINAL :

‘ [ T]he ORG has frequently indicated that it applies rigorous criteria and exercises close scrutiny when assessing the existence of a real risk of ill - treatment . . . in the event of a person being removed from the territory of the respondent ORG by extradition , expulsion or any other measure pursuing that aim . Although assessment of that risk is to some degree speculative , the ORG has always been very cautious , examining carefully the material placed before it in the light of the requisite standard of proof . . . before . . . finding that the enforcement of removal from the territory would be contrary to LAW . As a result , since adopting the PERSON judgment it has only rarely reached such a conclusion.’ ”
Therefore , for Lord PERSON , if a mandatory life sentence violated LAW in a domestic case , the risk of such a sentence would preclude extradition to another country .

CARDINAL . NORP However , despite these different views , none of ORG found that the sentence likely to be imposed on Mr GPE would be irreducible ; having regard to the commutation powers of the Governor of GPE , it would be just as reducible as the sentence at issue in GPE v. GPE [ ORG ] , no . CARDINAL , ECHR DATE .... All five Law Lords also noted that , in GPE , the ORG had only said that the imposition of an irreducible life sentence may raise an issue under LAW . They found that the imposition of a whole life sentence would not constitute inhuman and degrading treatment in violation of LAW , unless it were grossly or clearly disproportionate . Lord PERSON in particular noted :

“ Having puzzled long over this question , I have finally concluded that the majority of ORG [ in GPE ] would not regard even an irreducible life sentence — by which , as explained , I understand the majority to mean a mandatory life sentence to be served in full without there ever being proper consideration of the individual circumstances of the defendant ’s case — as violating article CARDINAL unless and until the time comes when further imprisonment would no longer be justified on any ground — whether for reasons of punishment , deterrence or public protection . CARDINAL . In ORG v. PERSON [ DATE ] ORG CARDINAL , ORG held that a mandatory sentence of CARDINAL years’ imprisonment for murder amounted to inhuman or degrading treatment in violation of section CARDINAL on the grounds that it was disproportionate .

CARDINAL . In ORG v. Tcoeib [ DATE ] CARDINAL LRC CARDINAL ORG considered the imposition of a discretionary life sentence to be compatible with section CARDINAL of the country ’s constitution ( subsection ( c ) of which is identical to LAW ) . Chief Justice PERSON , for the unanimous court , found the relevant statutory release scheme to be sufficient but observed that if release depended on the “ capricious exercise ” of the discretion of the prison or executive authorities , the hope of release would be “ too faint and much too unpredictable ” for the prisoner to retain the dignity required by section CARDINAL . It was also observed that life imprisonment could amount to cruel , inhuman or degrading treatment if it was grossly disproportionate to the severity of the offence . ORG of GPE found mandatory minimum sentences for robbery and possession of firearms to be grossly disproportionate in ORG v. PERSON CARDINAL LRC CARDINAL and ORG v Likuwa [ DATE ] CARDINAL LRC CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . In PERSON v. GPE [ DATE ] HKCFA CARDINAL , ORG rejected a challenge to the mandatory life sentence for murder . It found that the possibility of regular review of the sentence by an independent board meant it was neither arbitrary nor grossly disproportionate and thus it did not amount to cruel , inhuman or degrading punishment .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of GPE DATE also protects against disproportionately severe treatment or punishment .
